newsitem.title: BULGARIA: SOUTH KOREA STEPS UP BULGARIA INVESTMENT PLANS.
newsitem.headline: SOUTH KOREA STEPS UP BULGARIA INVESTMENT PLANS.

text.p: South Korean giants Daewoo Corp, Samsung Corp and Hyundai Corp have stepped up plans to invest in Bulgaria after the new government pledged to speed up sell-offs.
"We have presented to the new government two investment projects worth $50 million which await their approval," Lee Young Gik, manager of Samsung's Bulgarian subsidiary, told Reuters on Tuesday.

Samsung's first project proposes upgrading unleaded petrol production at Bulgaria's Neftochim refinery, and the second involves introducing environment protection technology at the Kremikovtsi metalworks, Bulgaria's biggest steel plant, said Lee.
Bulgaria will rely mostly on privatisation proceeds to sustain a currency board system due to be launched on July 1 to stabilise the currency and impose fiscal discipline.
One of the immediate effects of the system, which will peg the lev at 1,000 to the mark, will be to stabilise the business environment enabling investors to plan for the longer term.

A deal worth more than $10 million for acquisition of a majority stake in the Sofia-based electric components producer Elprom Trafo is expected to be concluded between Hyundai and the privatisation agency next month, a Hyundai official said.
South Korean investment in Bulgaria to date totals around $44 million.

Daewoo, which set up a local subsidiary in Bulgaria in 1992, will participate in a tender for 57 percent of the Chimko chemical fertiliser producer, said a company official. The Privatisation Agency has set a minimum price of $100.2 million for the stake after Daewoo's previous bid was deemed too low.

Daewoo is also vying for a stake in the Varna-based Expressbank with Austria's Raiffeisenbank and is negotiating participation in the Madara truck builder in Shumen, said a foreign investment agency official.
Daewoo bought 67 percent of Sofia's luxury Sheraton Sofia Hotel Balkan last year, pledging to invest some $5 million in it over the next five years.
Daewoo's Bulgarian subsidiary is also exporting disassembled Daewoo cars from Bulgaria to Russia and other former Soviet republics.
Daewoo has shown interest in investing in Bulgarian telecommunications, machine building and tourism. -- Sofia Newsroom 359-2-981-4145
